stream_context.summary: Kaze integrates a major graphical overhaul for Course 2 provided by artist Biobak. The stream focuses on importing new models (Yoshi, foliage, platforms), fixing the resulting technical and visual bugs, and iterating on asset implementation based on live feedback. Kaze also begins work on the candy-themed level inside the giant Yoshi, requiring a new collision map.

development_findings.summary: The team uses baked-in vertex colors for static level lighting, which Kaze deems a 'strictly superior technique' on the N64 for performance, despite sacrificing dynamic lighting effects.
development_findings.quote: For static level geometry like this, we can just bake the lighting right away, right? So it is just a strictly superior technique for static geometry without moving lights.

development_findings.summary: Kaze manually optimizes game performance by reordering actors in the level data to improve instruction cache efficiency, a low-level technique he prefers over modern engine architectures.
development_findings.quote: I made it so that all actors of the same code have like similar names and that makes it so that we get a little bit of better cache proximity which is very good.

development_findings.summary: A workflow is shown where Biobak provides new art assets and a changelog, and Kaze integrates them, debugs technical issues live, and iterates based on real-time feedback from Biobak in chat.
Kaze fixed a Z-clipping issue with grass on N64 hardware by altering the model to have the grass hang over further, hiding the visual artifact.
After fixing a major collision issue with the new Yoshi model, Kaze immediately identified a minor animation clipping issue and performed a small model edit himself to correct it.
development_findings.quote: He's fixed. It's one of the split tongues. Wait, what's wrong? His mouth did clip a little bit low when he opened his mouth, right? ... Okay. Unfortunately, I have to make a slight model edit for that then.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is actively working to eliminate all engine bugs and has successfully reduced compiler warnings to zero, indicating a focus on code stability and cleanliness.
Kaze struggles with a new version of Blender, expressing frustration over changes to vertex painting and rigging workflows while trying to implement Biobak's new Yoshi model.
The team is developing a candy-themed level that takes place inside the giant Yoshi, featuring assets like macarons, donuts, and watermelon platforms.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses immense pride in the game's visual quality, believing it surpasses any other N64 game.
context_findings.quote: I don't think you can even make the case that there's a better looking N64 game than this like anywhere in the world. I think it's just untrue.

context_findings.summary: Kaze holds a strong programming philosophy focused on understanding the low-level assembly instructions generated by his high-level C code, dismissing more abstract concepts.
context_findings.quote: There's only two programming languages and that's assembly and high level. And anything after that is mental illness.

context_findings.summary: Kaze dismisses modern or complex programming paradigms like ECS, preferring simpler, more direct optimization techniques like manually ordering actors in memory for better cache performance.
context_findings.quote: Entity component system is complete garbage. I can tell you that right now.

context_findings.summary: Kaze announced F3 2025, a sponsored fan-game event he is organizing, which will feature a cash prize for the most popular game to motivate developers.
Kaze describes his synesthetic experience of game design, associating the feeling of a well-designed level with a specific physical sensation.
context_findings.quote: Looking at a good level has the same feeling as, like, biting into a stream of flowing water, like, from a water hose.

context_findings.summary: Kaze launched a new merchandise store on TeePublic, with plans to create a unique t-shirt design for each course in the game.
Kaze jokes that his wife, Zeina, has banished him to the basement, where he does his streaming and development work.

biobak.summary: Biobak is leading a significant graphical rework of Course 2 (C10), providing Kaze with a large batch of new models and a changelog.
Biobak provides live feedback on Kaze's implementation of his assets, for instance, telling him the new bushes are 'a little too bright' which leads to an iterative adjustment.
Biobak created a new, higher-quality Yoshi model to replace the old one, prompting Kaze to go through the process of re-rigging and debugging it.
Biobak redesigned a collapsing floor trap to be a sliding floor, communicating the design intent and visual cues to Kaze via chat.
biobak.quote: No longer collapses inside, slides to the side, hence the scratch marks.

biobak.summary: Biobak's asset delivery sometimes requires technical fixes from Kaze, such as removing the use of 'environment color' which is incompatible with the engine's renderer.

zeina.summary: Kaze mentions Zeina in a personal, lighthearted context, joking about her 'banishing' him to the basement and her habit of calling a sausage a 'hot dog'.

key_stories.title: Importing the New Yoshi Model
key_stories.summary: Kaze integrated a new Yoshi model from Biobak, overcoming frustrations with Blender and a critical in-game bug. He diagnosed that the model was spawning incorrectly, preventing collision, and fixed it in the code, demonstrating his deep understanding of the engine.
key_stories.challenge: Biobak provided a new, visually improved Yoshi model that needed to be integrated into the game, replacing the old one.
key_stories.process: Kaze struggled with Blender's new UI to rig the model. After importing, he found it had no collision. He correctly diagnosed that the object was spawning with the wrong list type, preventing interaction. He changed the code to fix this, then made a small model edit to fix a mouth clipping animation.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze successfully imported the model and fixed the critical interaction bug. Although a minor dialogue bug remains, the new Yoshi is largely functional and visually superior.
key_stories.key_quote: I can guarantee you when I go there it's gonna say OBJ list spawner instead of surface. What did I say? What the fuck did I say? Huh? I knew it.

key_stories.title: Live Iteration on Foliage
key_stories.summary: Kaze and Biobak collaborated in real-time to perfect the look of new foliage. Biobak provided artistic direction via chat, and Kaze translated it into code, iterating on the color and brightness values until the in-game asset matched the intended vision.
key_stories.challenge: Biobak provided new foliage assets ('TempoBush') but the initial implementation did not match his artistic vision.
key_stories.process: Kaze first implemented the bushes with his existing random color system. Biobak, watching the stream, gave feedback in chat that they were too bright. Kaze then adjusted the color values in the code live on stream, showed the result, and added programmatic brightness variance to fine-tune the effect based on further feedback.
key_stories.outcome: Through this live feedback loop, they achieved a final look for the bushes that satisfied both of them, featuring randomized green and yellow tones with varied brightness.
key_stories.key_quote: A little too bright, at most as bright as the grass. Got it.

key_stories.title: The Windows Explorer Crash
key_stories.summary: Kaze's stream was interrupted by a Windows 11 bug that froze his taskbar. He demonstrated technical problem-solving by using the Task Manager to restart the Explorer process, fixing the issue without losing his work and showcasing a common frustration for developers.
key_stories.challenge: While in the middle of working, Kaze's Windows 11 taskbar and file explorer froze completely, preventing him from switching between applications.
key_stories.process: Kaze was initially unable to click on his taskbar. He used the Task Manager to manually switch windows. Following a suggestion from his chat, he located the 'Windows Explorer' process in the Task Manager and restarted it.
key_stories.outcome: By restarting the Windows Explorer process through the Task Manager, Kaze was able to restore full functionality to his desktop and continue the stream without rebooting.
key_stories.key_quote: Fucking Windows 11, I guess. Unironically, I probably did. Okay, I can go there like this. Weird. I can't click on my blender window anymore.

open_questions.context: After fixing the main issues with the new Yoshi model, Kaze discovered a persistent bug where Yoshi's dialogue is triggered twice. He briefly investigated the code but couldn't find the cause and decided to postpone fixing it.
questions: What was the eventual root cause of the Yoshi 'talking twice' bug?
Can you walk us through your debugging process for a non-critical but annoying bug like this?
How do you prioritize which bugs to fix now versus which to leave for later in the development cycle?

open_questions.context: Kaze announced 'F3 2025', a fan-game event he is organizing. He mentioned it is 'sponsored' this time and will feature a cash reward for the most popular game, but provided no further details.
questions: What is your vision for the F3 event and your role in the broader ROM hacking community?
Who is sponsoring the event, and how did that partnership come about?
What motivated you to introduce a cash prize, and what impact do you hope it has on the community?

open_questions.context: While integrating assets, Kaze told Biobak in chat, 'We're kind of threadlocked here,' and instructed him to wait for a GitHub push before making further changes to avoid conflicts.
questions: Can you elaborate on what you mean by being 'threadlocked' with Biobak?
What does your typical collaborative workflow look like, and how do you manage version control between art and code?
What are the biggest challenges in a remote collaboration where one person creates assets and another integrates them?

open_questions.topic: Professional and Personal Dynamic with Zeina
open_questions.context: Kaze made a few lighthearted jokes about his wife and fellow team member, Zeina, including that she 'banished' him to the basement to work.
questions: How does your personal relationship with Zeina influence your professional collaboration on the game?
Can you describe how you and Zeina give each other feedback on your respective work, like animation and code?
How do you navigate work-life balance when your spouse is also on your development team?

open_questions.topic: Concept and Design of the Candy Level
open_questions.context: The stream showed a level inside the giant Yoshi that is candy-themed, with macarons, donuts, and watermelon platforms. Kaze began the process of creating a new collision map for it due to Biobak's layout changes.
questions: What was the core creative idea behind putting a playable level inside of Yoshi?
How did the team land on a 'sweets and candy' theme for this particular level?
Are there any unique gameplay mechanics or challenges planned for the 'inside Yoshi' level that differ from other courses?
